Website Review for E-Commerce Brands

Ask yourself: What would you do with 10%, 20% or even 50% more money than you are currently making? (Take a few seconds to daydream.)

The Website Review gives you actionable advice on how you can increase revenue on your website by generating more sales and growing your email list.

The Website Review focuses on the most important changes you need to make to reach your goals.

It’s best to think of new visitors to your website as drunk sociopaths in a hurry.

You only have a few seconds in which to convince these new visitor to stay on your site, and if you make any part of your site the slightest bit confusing, your new visitor needs only to twitch their thumb to the back button to head back to Google and move on to your competition.

With so many competing websites, why would your prospect put up with a less than stellar website?

That’s why you need to design your website with the assumption that every visitor is a crazy, lazy drunk. That’s the key to a highly profitable website.

Let’s break down our user’s pathologies and what they mean for us:

  • The visitor is a sociopath. They care only about themselves, so you must write to them. The majority of e-commerce sites talk endlessly in the first person. “We’re the number 1 blah blah blah” Who cares? Talk to your visitor, hold up the mirror, describe them to themselves. I’m my favorite topic. That’s true of everyone. So always try to talk to your visitor about themselves. Share with them the value they will gain.
  • The visitor is lazy. If you put any undue restraints or requirements on the user, they will give up and leave your site. Have to click eight times to find your product? I’m leaving. No clear next step? I quit. Remove every friction point because we’re just that lazy.
  • The visitor is drunk. Let’s assume both my reading and decision-making abilities are impaired. Strip away all unnecessary garbage on your site. Make everything big and obvious. Reduce any unnecessary decisions by making those decisions for me in advance through defaults or removing them entirely. Though despite being drunk, visitors are deeply distrustful of you.

What if your website was your most effective sales person?

Is your potential customer actually a crazy, lazy drunk? No, of course not — okay maybe some of them — but if you adopt these extremes as a mindset, and design for them, then your website will work at its absolute best to convert visitors into customers and leads.

For an outstanding experience, you need to meet the needs of your visitors. People, when visiting your website, are goal-driven. They have a pain or need they need solved, and very little patience for your nonsense.

If your website meets the needs of your visitors by being easy-to-use and properly positioned, it will become the most effective sales person you have.

Learn how to make your website your most effective salesperson

Here’s the problem with web design: it’s focused too much on design, and not enough on results.

You may be at a loss when it comes to knowing if your website is set up properly.

Sure, you may have a great site— a beautiful site with wonderful content— but does it make you any money for your business? And if not, then why not, and how do you fix it? Even if you wanted to improve your website, most of us are left scratching our heads wondering where to even begin.

That’s where I come in.

I’ve built and optimized numerous very successful websites for myself and my clients over the last six years. I’ve learned, through experience, what it takes to build a website that doesn’t just look good, one that actually gets results.

Order Your Website Review Today

When you order a Website Review, this is what you’ll get

  • Website Review Video Recording — You’ll get a recorded ‘over the shoulder’ video from me (Jonathan Horst) that shows my experience going through your website as a first-time visitor. You’ll see, with fresh eyes, friction or issues that prevent me from accomplishing my goal on your website (~30–60 minutes long)
  • Your Questions, Answered — You’ll get answers to your most pressing questions about your website, increasing conversions, getting more subscribers, or selling more of your services
  • Executive Action Plan — After the review is complete, you’ll receive an executive action plan for your site: a detailed, executive summary level ~5–10+ point breakdown of the most important changes that I recommend. This summary is a perfect companion piece to the video, allowing you to have a punch list of the most important changes to make (making it so you don’t need to go back and watch the video several times yourself to digest the most important bits).

Here’s what your Website Review Video Recording will include:

  • A detailed and realistic impression of your current website
  • My thoughts and feedback in real-time as they happen
  • The “glaringly obvious” issues that you probably don’t see
  • A video recording of all the above (~30–60 minutes long)
  • An ‘Executive Action Plan’ summarizing the 5–10+ most important changes to make

“Is a Website Review effective? Does it work 100% of the time?”

You get out what you put in.

A Website Review is an excellent way to identify the top changes to make to your site to improve your conversion rate, retention strategy, or lead generation.

Will it work for your business? Depends on how much time, effort, and elbow grease you’re willing to invest in putting in the work to make the changes.

“Who is this not right for?”

This is not right for you if:

  • You’re looking for a ‘done for you’ option for optimizing your website
  • You aren’t comfortable investing $X00 in getting actionable, strategic advice on your website
  • You aren’t willing to put the time, effort, attention, and energy into implementing the advice yourself

If you don’t have a website, feel free to order a Website Review and save it for when you do have a website.

“Is this a magic bullet? Will my business be transformed?”

There are no magic bullets.

Website Reviews are a wonderful way for you to to get specific, actionable advice on what to fix (and what can stay the same) on your website.

You’ll still need to do the work.
